subject: Physical Fitness
title: Satellite Cells: The Repair Crew
description: One-minute skill: Satellite Cells: The Repair Crew.

hook.text: Hiding on the surface of every muscle fiber are dormant cells waiting for a damage signal.

buildup.text: When fibers tear during exercise, satellite cells activate. They divide and fuse into damaged areas.

discovery.text: They donate new nuclei to the fiber. More nuclei means more protein production and bigger muscles.

twist.text: These donated nuclei persist even during detraining. That's the basis of muscle memory.

climax.text: Aging depletes satellite cells. This is one reason elderly people build muscle more slowly.

punchline.text: Satellite cells are why damaged muscles come back bigger.

quiz.question: Why do donated nuclei from satellite cells matter for muscle memory?
options: They persist even when training stops, enabling faster regrowth
